unload.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to remove a load from a vehicle, ship etc
unload.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The driver unloaded some boxes from the back of the truck.
unload.translation[0].definitions[1].def: if a ship unloads, the goods that it carries are removed from it
unload.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to get rid of something illegal or not very good by selling it quickly
unload.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Investors continued to unload technology stocks on Thursday.
Hundreds of cheap videos were unloaded on the British market.
unload.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to get rid of work or responsibility by giving it to someone else
unload.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Donâ€™t let him unload his problems onto you.
unload.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to express strong feelings, especially anger, to someone when you are extremely upset
unload.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Koch unloaded his concerns over dinner one night.
When he got back to the office, Green unloaded on his staff.
unload.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to remove the film from a camera
unload.translation[0].definitions[6].def: to remove the bullets from a gun
unload.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to remove a load from a vehicle, ship etc
unload.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Delivery people were unloading fax machines.
This is where the ships load and unload.
unload.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to get rid of something quickly, especially by selling large quantities, for example because its price is falling
unload.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The poor economy prompted investors to unload shares.
Their U.S. government bond desk unloaded $20 billion in government securities.
